element.title: PREPROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS:
element.text: Physical examination of leg and back.

element.title: POSTPROCEDURE DIAGNOSES:
element.text: (1) L5 nerve impingement from a herniated disc is observed. (2) This is causing weakness in the ankle. (3) This is also causing the pain may also radiate into the buttock.

element.title: PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
element.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).

element.title: ENDOSCOPIST:
element.text: Michael Jones, M.D.

element.title: ASSISTANT:
element.text: Jane Doe, L.P.N.

element.title: REFERRING PHYSICIAN:
element.text: George Washington, M.D.

element.title: ANESTHESIA:
element.text: Demerol 25 mg IV push, Versed 2 mg IV push.

element.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:
element.text: Informed consent was obtained. Rectal examination by finger was unremarkable. The scope was introduced all the way up to the cecum without any difficulty. There was extensive diverticulosis throughout the colon. The following findings were noted in a very well-prepped colon: 1. Cecum and ascending colon also showed some mild diverticulosis. 2. Transverse colon shows moderate diverticulosis. 3. Sigmoid and descending colon show extensive diverticulosis. A single diverticulum in the sigmoid colon is very large and has ulceration in the middle of it. This suggests the patient had acute diverticulitis, but more likely nonsteroidal-induced ulceration. 4. Rectum is unremarkable except for multiple small superficial polyps which are most likely hyperplastic. Also, internal hemorrhoids are noted.

element.title: DIAGNOSTIC IMPRESSION:
element.text: The patient's rectal bleeding is probably coming from the internal hemorrhoids with the finding of polyps incidental.

element.title: PLAN:
element.text: 1. Follow up polyp pathology. Most likely, this will be hyperplastic. If hyperplastic, the value of further colonoscopies in this 80-year-old lady in not so perfect health is limited. 2. In 5 years, we can review how she is and consider a colonoscopy and followup. I would favor the approach of not performing any further intervention at that time.

element.title: PREPROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS:
element.text: Polyp formation in the nasal cavity is due to chronic allergic rhinitis and chronic sinusitis.

element.title: POSTPROCEDURE DIAGNOSES:
element.text:
(1) Extensive diverticulosis throughout the sinus.
(2) Internal polyps - the cause of bleeding.
(3) Ulceration of the sigmoid diverticulum. Differential diagnosis: Mild diverticulitis or aspirin-induced loremispsum.
(4) Multiple small nasal polyps.

element.title: PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
element.text: Endoscopy with ultrasound.

element.title: ENDOSCOPIST:
element.text: Michael Jones, M.D.

element.title: ASSISTANT:
element.text: Jane Doe, L.P.N.

element.title: REFERRING PHYSICIAN:
element.text: George Washington, M.D.

element.title: ANESTHESIA:
element.text: Demerol 25 mg IV push, Versed 2 mg IV push.

element.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:
element.text:
Informed consent was obtained. Nasal examination by finger was unremarkable. The scope was introduced all the way up to the nasal passage without any difficulty. There was extensive diverticulosis throughout the sinus.

The following findings were noted in a very well-prepped sinus:

1. Superior turbinate also showed some mild diverticulosis.

2. Lacrimal sac shows moderate diverticulosis.

3. Sigmoid and inferior turbinate show extensive diverticulosis. A single diverticulum in the inferior turnbinate is very large and has ulceration in the middle of it. This suggests the patient had acute diverticulitis, but more likely nonsteroidal-induced ulceration.

4. Naso-lacrimal duct is unremarkable except for multiple small superficial polyps which are most likely hyperplastic. Also, internal polyps are noted.

element.title: DIAGNOSTIC IMPRESSION:
element.text: The patient's sinus bleeding is probably coming from the finding of polyps.

element.title: PLAN:
element.text: 1. Follow up polyp pathology. Most likely, this will be hyperplastic. If hyperplastic, the value of further endoscopies in this 80-year-old lady in not so perfect health is limited.\n\n2. In 5 years, we can review how she is and consider a endooscopy and followup. I would favor the approach of not performing any further intervention at that time.
